captions.text:
Why did the chicken cross the road? We may
never know, since she probably never got to

the other side. In the US alone, about a million
animals are flattened by passing motorists

each day – and that doesn’t count all
the bugs!

Animals are constantly confronted with barriers,
some of them completely natural, and others

that we build that are barely barriers at
all. As we build our own infrastructure, we’re

also adding to this obstacle course without
meaning to, and these unintentional fences

are some of the most effective animal barriers
out there. Roads are just the beginning.

Take high-tension power lines, for example.
They may look harmless to us, but many other

creatures steer clear. We can’t say why
for sure, but these animals’ ultraviolet

vision may mean that the UV flashes discharging
from the cables make for a very scary sight.

And even weirder stuff can get in animals’
way. Many hoofed mammals are hesitant to cross

linear features like clear-cut corridors,
pipelines – even rows of rocks or painted

lines on the ground – leaving them psychologically
stranded on one side or the other.

While one stranded cow might not be a huge
problem, if enough animals become isolated

from food, mates, and protection, entire populations
can dwindle and even disappear.

One solution would be to get rid of all these
obstacles, but we aren’t likely to give

up roads, power, or pipelines any time soon.
And even when we remove physical barriers,

their stopping power can stick around. The
“Iron Curtain” between the Czech Republic

and Germany was torn down more than 20 years
ago, but red deer still won’t cross that

divide. Generations of fawns learned to avoid
the barbed wire fence, and even with it gone,
the lessons live on.

Luckily, a little ingenuity goes a long way
in guiding animals over, under, or around

the obstacles we put in their way. Just as
a footbridge helps us cross dangerous roads,

we can build overpasses that help deer, monkeys,
and crabs do the same. Elephants go underneath

, and we’ve even engineered salmon cannons
to help fish sail past dams on their way upriver.

We can bridge mental barriers too, encouraging
animals to cross obstacles that could otherwise
psych them out.

In the end, even if we don’t know why the
chicken crossed the road, at least we can
help her get there safely.

comments.text:
Highways don't have pedestrians like metropolis, or even suburb areas do, +
cOmAtOrAn let's think this through -- we're lucky to catch a deer in time 
on the highway, so even at slower speeds, what kind of chance to we have to 
see a much smaller child quick enough to react (especially taking into 
consideration elderly drivers who have notably slower reaction times, & 
teen drivers, who statistically drive more recklessly).

Also, you make an excellent point -- street lamps have many more uses than 
just helping drivers to see pedestrians.  I can imagine a spike in crime if 
a city were to turn off all their street lights, can't you?
comments.author: Clayton ­

comments.text:

Headlights are bright enough, which is why there aren't lights lining every

comments.author: Gearfire

comments.text:
After backpacking a highway between my home and a state park this week I 
noticed way more roadkill and non-biodegradable litter than I did driving 
past at 55 mph. I concluded that speeding by on our highways 
psychologically compresses the space that includes the road and its 
margins. Speeding by doesn't allow us to think about that land in the same 
way as our lawns, parks, even city streets, which diminishes our sense of 
responsibility to care for it.﻿

comments.author: Kudi

comments.text:
+Amber James Well, first of all, my dear friend, you are not a lion, you 
are a homo sapiens, so using lion behavior as an excuse for human behavior 
is a pretty weak argument, don´t you think? Or do you run around naked, 
sniff peoples assholes and shit outdoors? And do you think that if you took 
a dump in your neighbors garden and then said to him: Hey man, that´s 
natural, Lions do it too!
Second when I see those fellows from the hunting associations drunk in a 
pub and bragging and arguing over who shoot the biggest and most beautiful 
deer, then I am sorry, my friend, I cannot share your opinion about hunting 
and hunters. It's not like nature has taken care of itself the last ... 
 how old is life as we know it again...? Oh yeah, only about 500 Millions 
years. And how pathetic is someone who can´t enjoy the beauty of nature 
without killing fish, deers, birds, etc. for fun.
And overpopulation? Now honestly, if you think that deer population, or any 
animal population is threatening do overpopulate the planet and destroy 
like all live habitat, if we humans didn´t kill, torture and eat them, then 
I think it is a bit weird that the global media are not full of headlines 
like: COW CRISIS IN INDIA → EAT MORE COWS or DEER CATASTROPHY IN ALASKA, 
THE HUNTERS OF THE WORLD MUST DO THEIR DUTY ONCE AGAIN. Nature knows how to 
take care of itself, problem is, this evolutionary accidents homo sapiens 
is convinced that he knows everything better and so he must intervene 
everywhere where he sees fit.
But if the cyle of killing for fun,bloodshed, cruelty, torture and death 
sounds good and natural to you, then, my dear fellow, maybe a little more 
skepticism about the things society thinks as normal, good and necessary 
wouldn´t harm you too much. But that is only my humble opinion.
comments.author: Kudi

comments.text:
No matter what, animals are dying everyday for food. Lions kill deer for 
food, it's the natural system. Honestly, if we weren't here to kill fish, 
or to hunt deer, then there could be overpopulation of deer and other prey, 
because we are viewed as predators too. But I do agree with the pollution 
and such. We are in such a shit hole that we dug for ourselves it's not 
funny. But, we are building bridges and such, so that we can make sure that 
there isn't a major decrease in animal population, that why there are 
places where you cannot fish, or hunt at. So, sure killing animals is part 
of the natural cycle of things, but we should also make sure that the 
animal populations don't decrease. That's how I feel, anyways.
comments.author: Amber James

comments.text:
The power line avoidance is not true.  My husband and I walk past those 
exact type of power lines and find dead birds lying on the ground directly 
beneath them.  One other point: Why was this titled Five CRAZY Bridges? 
 Why not Five Conscientious Bridges?  Humans have been 'developing' (I say 
destroying) large portions of natural areas in an effort to make their 
lives easier (ie roadways) with NO conscious thought to all the creatures 
that share this planet. I say that is self-centered, egotistical and 
ignorant. We need to change.﻿

Roads are a necessary part of the modern world. We couldn't function the 
same without them. Human achievement is built off of human achievement. The 
invention of things like roads is a root to numerous other achievements 
later on. The only way to truly have no negative effect on the natural 
world around us would be to start living like we did 9,000 years ago, which 
I'm willing to bet that most of us (even you) would not be quite ready to 
do.
comments.author: Gearfire
